segments.text: to use our experience as a launching platform where perhaps we might reach an even higher level of achievement in the future.
It was at that
It was at the last of those three commencements on Saturday morning that Dr. Miller failed to shake hands with Melanie Zentgraf.
An action dash or lack thereof dash on his part
which would later be thrust at him by the Board of Regents less than two months later.
In the 70s, I continued to speak at Musters and many other A&M related events, such as former student meetings in various Texas communities and A&M Mothers Club sessions as well.
Each of those muster were special and quite often unique.
For example, at an outdoor session on the beach near Galveston, our biggest problems included the noises of waves and the
constant irritation of mosquitoes and other bugs.
On another occasion, at a West Texas muster, which was intended to be an old-fashioned Texas potluck,
event where everybody was to bring something.
Someone forgot to bring plates and tableware and then they realized that no one had made iced tea.
A very special
Aggie memory that could come only at an A&M event occurred in one of my early years when I spoke at the muster in Fort Worth.
Before I was very far into my remarks,
A senior former student called out from the back of the room, quote, what kind of Aggie are you?
You didn't even go to school there.
Being challenged with a truly unanticipated question, I paused and attempted to escape
his possible scorn by pointing out that although I had not attended A&M, I was an Aggie by choice.
He sprang to his feet and responded, what the hell does that mean?
And I attempted to explain that although I had not gone to A&M, I had had other offers of employment at various times, but had made the decision to remain there.
And then an idea popped in my brain, which I voiced when I looked at him and said, but I have understood that some people didn't have a choice about whether or not they attended A&M.
Back on his feet, this time with a smile.
He.
Agreed.
Quote you're right.
In the fall of 28.
My dad called me into our house on a farm.
Up near Jacksboro.
And told me I could stay there that fall.
and pick cotton, or I could go to College Station and maybe they'd straighten me out."
Period quote.
A&M club meetings, former student club meetings, Aggie Mothers sessions, meeting with high school counselors when they came to the campus, and many other appearances of that sort.
Now in hindsight,
appear to have been, appear to have been excellent preparation for the off-campus responsibilities of a senior academic administrator, especially a campus CEO.
I remember going to Aggie Fish Camp almost every year at their gathering at a Methodist youth retreat not far from Palestine.
My normal assignment was to try to explain
the philosophy of land grant education and Texas A&M's role in meeting the challenges of the Morrill Act, M-O-R-R-I-L-L.
In those remarks,
I attempted to emphasize that the Morrill Act passed by the Federal Congress in 1862 was adopted by the Texas legislature in the early 1870s.
And then those representatives and senators
identified Brazos County as the location for the Agricultural Mechanical College of Texas, the first public institution in the Lone Star State.
I tried to assure these incoming students that the federal
Act mandated that all land grant schools must offer preparation in agriculture, comma, quote, the mechanic arts, quote, which I always interpreted as
in today's lingo as engineering and technology, comma, and military instruction, which today we label as ROTC training.
Then I was
very careful to try to proceed beyond that and to indicate that in no way did the Morrill Act limit land-grant schools to only those three areas of opportunity.
And I tried to make these incoming freshmen aware that Texas A&M
hoped to be far more inclusive and was on its way and was striving to add to its breadth and depth every year.
Fish Camp, quote, paragraph, Fish Camp always seemed to be a very meaningful
and splendid introduction to incoming freshmen from all backgrounds with a wide variety of goals.
Male and female, civilian and corps, urban, rural, domestic and international,
Similarly, when they left the two or three days of fish camp, there seemed to be already a foundation of spirit and togetherness.
held together by an increasing flow of maroon-tinted blood.
Another of those bonding events, of course, was Bonfire, which in our first years was held
In the early 60s on the drill field.
And then moved over to the area south of Duncan Dining Hall.
Students worked on.
That on building that stack of logs.
To be.
Ignited the night before.
Home games with the Longhorns.
Or on Tuesday night.
If the game was in Austin.
The stacks did not seem very high.
Back.
View from.
the elevation of the night bonfires in the late 1990s.
Students worked there.
And those of us who lived in the area and had fireplaces would quite often go over

a day or two after bonfire was over and cut up the remainder of the small timber that had been left out of the big stack and towed it home very much with the permission and encouragement of campus authorities
who were grateful not to have to haul that rubbish to a landfill.
Paragraph, during those same years I felt an increasing obligation as I rose in
in responsibility on the campus to become even more involved in the community.
This particularly included service at the First Presbyterian Church in Bryan as a deacon and elder and for a number of years as a Sunday school class.
as Sunday school class teacher.
We had a very, a group that gathered early in the 1960s of young couples with an apparent, almost uncountable sum of
children from infants into elementary school.
As we organized that group, we made one congregationally impolitic decision when we named ourselves the
Okay, gonna stop and look at peaches.
Had to stop east of Fredericksburg to buy some peaches at an orchard run, believe it or not, by a German.
His name is George Peel, P-E-H-L.
Somehow, somebody I think could make some fun out of the fact that he was selling
that his peaches had peelings or that they were, he grew them and therefore they had been peeled.
That impolitic step we made was to name our Sunday school class the young couples class.
Most of us were well below the age of 35 years or so.
And therefore, we did not anticipate the frustration and clear disappointment by some older married folks who attended
who were members of, quote, the couples class, quote, because they thought we were deliberately trying to infer that they were old and we were young.
Paragraph.
In that Sunday school group of friends,
were a number of folks who would become true life acquaintances and who we would count as among our closest friends forever.
As my wife and others often said, we had the joy of being poor and raising children together.
Another similar paragraph.
Another community experience was to serve on the board of the City National Bank in Bryan.
That relationship came almost entirely because of our acquaintance with Bookman Peters.
whom I first remember encountering in the hallway of the First Presbyterian Church one day in Bryan, one day between Sunday school and worship service.
He was then at the first bank and trust in Bryan, and he urged me to
consider moving our account downtown.
I tried to remind him that I was only an instructor and certainly our account would not make much profit for any financial institution.
He optimistically predicted that I would not always be at that rank.
And his encouragement led me to move the account.
Then when his family purchased the city national, we moved our account there.
And then in the 70s, I was honored to be invited to join the board of that bank.
Paragraph now in hindsight.
One of the most.
Now in sad hindsight, one of the most memorable.
Events.
Of that.
Community involvement.
Was the day when we?
Voted.
To accept what seemed to be a very generous stock swap merger offer.
Between the City National Bank.
of Bryan and the First City National Bank of Houston.
We had other offers at that time from the Republic Bank and the Mercantile National Bank, both of Dallas.
And as I later told my colleagues,
On that particular day, we couldn't miss by accepting any of those three dash because they all went bankrupt.

of the old Board of Regents house just north of Sabeasa and lived beneath the quarters for the Texas A&M Press on the second floor of that old structure.
That peace and quiet was destroyed one night
when Mrs. Williams said she heard an A&M campus fireman yelling, y'all get out, your house is on fire.
They dashed out to their personal safety, but lost many of their sentimentally irreplaceable belongings.
The press suffered great damage also, even losing much
of the original drafts of the A&M Press mark, which had been created by Tom Lee, the great El Paso artist.
The press found temporary quarters in a warehouse,
And the Williams moved off campus.
Before too long they relocated to Houston.

for all of the medical facilities and instructional institutions in that great conglomeration in Houston.

I am deeply frustrated at myself that I did not remain in closer contact with that one of a kind role model for me as an academic administrator.
He will always be for me
The splendid leader.

Compared.

We moved to El Paso.
Was a deep personal loss.
The board selected Frank Hubert, Dean of Education, to replace Dr. Williams as the chief executive of the system.
So he moved into the system administration building, now named the Jack Williams building.
on the east end of the campus facing Texas Avenue.
Soon we became aware of a deep disagreement between the new chancellor and President Miller over the reporting location of the
various system agencies, including the Agricultural and Mechanical Experiment Stations, Extension Services and the Texas Forest Service.
Dr. Miller, who as
Director of the Agricultural Experiment Station had not want to report to the campus.
But now as president, he urged the board to place those agencies under his administrative review.
He had
some reason to do so because so much of the budget for the colleges of agriculture, engineering, and veterinary medicine came from the stations and the services.
Naturally, the heads of those agencies did not want to report to the campus
But preferred.
To go to the head man.
Of the system.
